captions.text:
I have prepared 
a completely different talk,

but after listening to the news
of the riots of last Black Friday,

I decided to change my talk
and we're going to talk about enoughness.

So do you ever ask yourselves:
"How much is enough?"

Enough to make you happy?
Enough to carry you into the future?

Well, I have asked myself
this question as well,

and so I set out to find some clues
in the wisdom of indigineous people.
The images you are going to see behind me
are snippets from stories I have worked on
for the past twenty years.

My camera has taken me
to about a hundred countries
in every continent in the world.
And I have used it to shine a light
on issues related to conservation,
but particularly on the point
where healthy ecosytems intersect
with the faith of indigenous people.
I have been extremely lucky

to spend a lot of time
in the solitude of nature

and in the company of people
who live isolated but are self-sufficient,

and they carve their living
with their own bare hands

that is full of meaning
and full of poetry.

And it is from them that I've started
thinking about enoughness.

To start off,
I wanted to tell you a story.
I just came back from Hawaii.
I arrived yesterday, hence the tan.

And I have been working there
for National Geographic magazine,

doing a story on the traditional
Hawaiian culture.

While I was there I had the opportunity
of photographing a man named Keone Nunes,

and he is a master
of the ancient art of Kakau,
which is traditional tattoo.

While he was working
on this young man's tattoo,

he told me that he grew up
in a shack on the beach

without much wealth, but surrounded
by his "ohana," his family.
And seeped deep in tradition,
and speaking his native Hawaiian language,

and surfing on one of the most beautiful
beaches on the world with all his friends.

He said to me: "I never knew I was poor
until somebody from the mainland told me."
"I always thought I had enough."
And that to me was a huge revelation.
His story resonated with me,

because this is something that I've seen
in many traditional societies.

We judge them as poor
by our own standards,

but many of them
are actually quite content. Why?

I have learned a lot
from indigenous people.
One of the things that I have learned

is that our happiness is only due
about 10% to material stuff.

So where do the other 90%
that makes us feel good come from?

And it is not
from material things, you know.

Contentment is something 
that is long-lasting,
that comes from inside,

and it's basically 
the satisfaction of knowing
what our place in the universe is.
So if I had to define enoughness,

I would tell you
that it's an internal yardstick.
It's something that only we can develop

And if indigenous people
have been doing it for so long,

maybe this is something
we can learn for ourselves.

And maybe this is a tool 
that would carry us

into that sustainable future
that we all dream about.

So let me tell you first 
that enoughness is amazing

because it really cuts across
all indigenous cultures.
It doesn't matter where you go.

And it basically distills to
if you have clean water,
a net full of fish and a warm fire.

That's basically all people need
to feel quite content.
I photographed this girl,

she is from a Vezo tribe
in western Madagascar
and she was coming home

after trying to catch supper
for her family.
She didn't have much luck,
but she was incredibly proud

because she has been given
this amazing responsibility
And I remember thinking, at the time,

she was not much older
than my own daughter.

And I certainly would not have trusted
my daughter with boiling a hot dog,

let alone bringing dinner 
for the whole family!

But it also got me thinking that 
when you give responsibility
to every member of a family

or every member of a community,
to share and pull in together

collaborating to make sure 
that everybody is ok,
that is a great way to build enoughness.

I love this photograph because
it reminds me
that you can be very serious about culture
but without sacrificing fun.

These gentlemen are from a tribe
of Eastern islands in Papa New Guinea

They compete every year, they get together
and they have this huge festival.

Thousands of people dressed up
come and they compete to see
who is the most traditional.

They are not only super proud 
of who they are,
their traditions and their culture,
they want to share it.
This is my friend Pointuc

She is the eldest daughter
of Chief Pukachiti,
who lives in a village in the Amazon.

I have been lucky to trek with Pointuc
many times into the forest.

She is amazing, she can find
this invisible trails that I don't see.

She can find where the "Açaí" tree
- have you ever tried "Açaí"? -

where it grows and then she climbs 
up the tree about 40 feet

even when she is pregnant
and with her machete,
she will cut it down and bring it down.

Pointuc has actually tried to teach me
how to navigate the river

and how to build a fire and although
some days I like to fantasize
that I am as capable as Pointuc,

the truth is that I am
an ignorant outsider

with a lot of expensive gear 
around my neck. (Laughter)

The thing the Pointuc has really taught me
is that I need not take me so seriously.

Humor is another great way 
of building enoughness.

Late one afternoon I was able 
to photograph these beautiful girls

as they were taking a bath 
in a river in the Amazon
in this beautiful waterfall.
I remember thinking,

"God, these girls are lucky,
they don't have a worry in the world"

The river and the forest provide
everything they need.

They do not have to worry
whether Miley Cyrus is twerking,
(Laughter)

if she is peer pressure
or Justin Bieber...

One of the things I remember thinking
is that these girls own almost nothing
beyond the little clothes they're wearing,

but if you look at their bodies,
they are painted.

That painting is part
of a very rich tradition

that ties them deeply 
to every member of their family

as part of the social bonding
is how they paint each other.

That sense of connection is what makes
huge part of enoughness.

All across the world, indigenous people
and the families everywhere

having this sense of connection to 
each other, to the environment, to ritual,

that's what gives meaning 
and purpose to our lives,
and that's what builds enoughness.

Whether I am trekking in the forest 
of the Yunan province in China,

with people still remember
where their sacred foods grow,

or visiting the underworld 
with Mayan people,
I've visited the watery graves

where our ancestors were buried
thousands of years ago,

I always try to think
about how much is enough.

And one of the best places
to find enoughness is in the arts.

Indigenous people have perfected
their artistic skills.
And some of them take it over the top.
(Laughter)

For many of them, art, the fine arts, 
arts and craft,

body ornamentation
is part of a rich spiritual life.

This man is an "Asaro Mudmen"
from the islands of Papua New Guinea.

He believes that if he dresses himself up
like the mud of the Asaro river,
his enemies will not be able to see him.

And what about play? We pity children,
like indigenous children
will never get a chance to go to school.

We feel sorry for them, but the truth is,
they get to be creative in their play.
And they play outdoors all the time,

and what they are learning
is real-life skills:

they learn how to weave,
how to cook, how to hunt,

and can you imagine
the creative potential of people

who are never hooked
to an iphone or a computer?

The other thing that is interesting
about indigenous people

is that we are always worried about 
investing and saving for the future.

For them, they live in the day-to-day,
they live so present and in the moment.
And that too is part of their enoughness.

So I have been incredibly lucky 
to spend a lot of time

with people that still
remember the old ways

in which every productive activity,
be it hunting or harvesting or fishing,

still resonates with meaning
and with respect for the land.
Whether it is the Pantaneros of Brazil
or the fisherman of Abrolhos in Bahia,

everything that they do shines
with the brightness of enoughness.

Sadly, a lot of indigenous people
are experiencing something

that James Cameron would call
an "Avatar" syndrome.

And they are having to fight
the mighty power of the industrial world

with their own bare hands,
like these chiefs of the Kayapo.

The third largest 
hydro-electric dam in the world

is about to be built
on the beautiful river they call home.
Or the Gitga'at people of British Columbia

who are fighting to keep
mega-tankers out of their waters.
Tankers bigger than the Exxon Valdez.

For them, it's not if, but when
an oil spill happens.
It would destroy their entire livelihood.
So I want my images to remind us
that when all the rivers have been dammed,

and all the forests have been turned
into chopsticks,

and the last wild creature
has been hunted for trophy,
we will all be a lot poorer.

But it's people like this Antandroy
woman from Madagascar

who lives on the razor's edge
between poverty and nature,

that will be left feeling
less than enough.

The reason it matters is because
people who are living
a sustainable life today,

like this Miskito fisherman from Honduras
who dives for lobsters to feed his family,

or this young girl from 
the foothills of the Andes

who watches 
her family's sheep after school,

They will be left
with less than enough to eat.

So I encourage us all to go back
to the initial question
and ask "how much is enough?"

I know the answer for myself
and I ask myself everyday

with every consumer choice,
with everything I buy.

But if we turn the mirror 
of enoughness towards you,
maybe you will start asking yourself.
And maybe that will lead us to

that sustainable future
that we all dream about.
Thank you so much.
(Applause)
